section.name: Notational Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 [RFC2119].

section.name: Baseline Profile
section.t: OIDF FAPI is an API security profile based on the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework . It aims to reach the security goals laid out in the [Attacker Model].

section.name: Network Layer Protections
section.t: To protect against network attackers, clients, authorization servers, and resource servers MUST only offer TLS protected endpoints and MUST establish connections to other servers using TLS. TLS connections MUST be set up to use TLS version 1.2 or later and follow .

Endpoints for the use by web browsers MUST use methods to ensure that connections cannot be downgraded using TLS Stripping attacks. A preloaded HTTP Strict Transport Security policy can be used for this purpose. Some top-level domains, like .bank and .insurance, have set such a policy and therefore protect all second-level domains below them.

For a comprehensive protection against network attackers, all endpoints SHOULD additionally use DNSSEC to protect against DNS spoofing attacks that can lead to the issuance of rogue domain-validated TLS certificates. Note: Even if an endpoint uses only organization validated (OV) or extended validation (EV) TLS certificates, rogue domain-validated certificates can be used to impersonate the endpoints and conduct man-in-the-middle attacks.

section.name: Profile
section.t: In the following, a profile of the following technologies is defined:

li.t: OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework
OAuth 2.0 Bearer Tokens
OAuth 2.0 PKCE
OAuth 2.0 Mutual-TLS Client Authentication
OAuth 2.0 Pushed Authorization Requests (PAR)
OAuth 2.0 Rich Authorization Requests (RAR)
OAuth 2.0 Authorization Server Metadata
OpenID Connect Core 1.0 incorporating errata set 1

section.name: Requirements for Authorization Servers

li.t: MUST adhere to
MUST support the authorization code grant described in
MUST support client-authenticated pushed authorization requests according to
MUST NOT support authorization requests sent without or authorization request parameters sent outside of the PAR request, except for request_uri
MUST NOT support pushed authorization requests without client authentication
MUST support rich authorization requests according to
MUST support confidential clients as defined in
MUST support and sender-constraining of access tokens using Mutual TLS as described in
MUST authenticate clients using one of the following methods:
Mutual TLS for OAuth Client Authentication as specified in section 2 of
private_key_jwt as specified in section 9 of
MUST require PKCE with S256 as the code challenge method
MUST only issue authorization codes, access tokens, and refresh tokens that are sender-constrained
MUST require the redirect_uri parameter in authorization requests and evaluate only this parameter to ensure authenticity and integrity of the redirect URI
MUST require that redirect URIs use the https scheme
MUST verify, if possible, that the authorization code (section 1.3.1 of [RFC6749]) has not been previously used

MUST provide a means for resource servers to verify the validity, integrity, sender-constraining, scope (incl. authorization_details), expiration and revocation status of an access token, either by providing an introspection endpoint , by exposing signature verification keys, or by deployment-specific means.

section.t: NOTE: If replay identification of the authorization code is not possible, it is desirable to set the validity period of the authorization code to one minute or a suitable short period of time. The validity period may act as a cache control indicator of when to clear the authorization code cache if one is used.

section.name: Returning Authenticated User's Identifier
section.t: If it is desired to provide the authenticated user's identifier to the client in the token response, the authorization server:

li.t: MUST support the authentication request as in Section 3.1.2.1 of
MUST perform the authentication request verification as in Section 3.1.2.2 of
MUST authenticate the user as in Section 3.1.2.2 and 3.1.2.3 of
MUST provide the authentication response as in Section 3.1.2.4 and 3.1.2.5 of depending on the outcome of the authentication
MUST perform the token request verification as in Section 3.1.3.2 of

MUST issue an ID Token in the token response when openid was included in the requested scope as in Section 3.1.3.3 of with its sub value corresponding to the authenticated user and optional acr value in ID Token.
MUST use the authorization code grant described in
MUST use pushed authorization requests according to
MUST use sender-constrained access tokens using Mutual TLS as described in
MUST support client authentication using one of the following methods:
Mutual TLS for OAuth Client Authentication as specified in section 2 of
private_key_jwt as specified in section 9 of
MUST use PKCE with S256 as the code challenge method
MUST send access tokens in the HTTP header as in Section 2.1 of OAuth 2.0 Bearer Token Usage [RFC6750]

MAY send the last time the customer logged into the client in the x-fapi-auth-date header where the value is supplied as a HTTP-date as in section 7.1.1.1 of [RFC7231], e.g., x-fapi-auth-date: Tue, 11 Sep 2012 19:43:31 GMT
MAY send the customer’s IP address if this data is available in the x-fapi-customer-ip-address header, e.g., x-fapi-customer-ip-address: 198.51.100.119

MAY send the x-fapi-interaction-id request header whose value is a [RFC4122] UUID to the server to help correlate log entries between client and server, e.g., x-fapi-interaction-id: c770aef3-6784-41f7-8e0e-ff5f97bddb3a

section.name: Requirements for Resource Servers
section.t: The FAPI 2.0 endpoints are OAuth 2.0 protected resource endpoints that return protected information for the resource owner associated with the submitted access token.
Resource servers with the FAPI endpoints

li.t: MUST accept access tokens in the HTTP header as in Section 2.1 of OAuth 2.0 Bearer Token Usage [RFC6750]
MUST not accept access tokens in the query parameters stated in Section 2.3 of OAuth 2.0 Bearer Token Usage [RFC6750]
MUST verify the validity, integrity, expiration and revocation status of access tokens
MUST verify that the scope (incl. authorization_details) of the access token authorizes the access to the resource it is representing
MUST verify sender-constraining for access tokens
MUST identify the associated entity to the access token
MUST only return the resource identified by the combination of the entity implicit in the access and the granted scope and otherwise return errors as in section 3.1 of [RFC6750]

MUST set the response header x-fapi-interaction-id to the value received from the corresponding fapi client request header or to a [RFC4122] UUID value if the request header was not provided to track the interaction, e.g., x-fapi-interaction-id: c770aef3-6784-41f7-8e0e-ff5f97bddb3a
MUST log the value of x-fapi-interaction-id in the log entry
RSA keys MUST have a minimum length of 2048 bits.
Elliptic curve keys MUST have a minimum length of 160 bits.
authorization servers MUST provide a client secret that adheres to the requirements in section 16.19 of if a symmetric key is used

Access tokens MUST be non-guessable with a minimum of 128 bits of entropy where the probability of an attacker guessing the generated token is less than or equal to 2^(-160) as per [RFC6749] section 10.10.
